references: Table 1 reports the performance comparisons among several federated learning models for zero-shot recognition.

Federated Baselines: We compare the proposed approach with the most representative federated learning frameworks FedAvg [27], FedAvg-decay [23], and FedProx [25]. FedAvg learns a global model by aggregating parameters from local devices, which is nearly the same as Baseline (Ï†=0.1ğœ‘0.1\varphi=0.1) but with an additional server aggregation step. Table 1 shows that FedAvg with Ï†=0.1ğœ‘0.1\varphi=0.1 can obtain comparable results with baseline (Ï†=0.5ğœ‘0.5\varphi=0.5). As clients do not take advantage of the semantic attributes, FedAvg fails to achieve significant performance gains for the unseen classes over baselines. FedAvg-decay has an extra requirement on the global learning rate. By decaying the learning rate of global aggregation, the performance results on CUB and SUN are improved comparing with FedAvg. FedProx is a federated baseline tackling heterogeneity, which assigns higher aggregation rates to the clients that hold more training data. However, our experiments show that in our proposed p.c.c.d. setting, simply associating aggregation rate with the amount of data fails to achieve better performance.

Ablation Study.
In this ablation study, we evaluate various stripped-down versions of our full proposed model to
validate different components of the proposed FedZSL. In Table 2, we report the ZSL and GZSL performance of each version on the three benchmark datasets. The best performance is achieved when the CARD training strategy with the KL loss function â„“kâ€‹lsubscriptâ„“ğ‘˜ğ‘™\ell_{kl} and the semantic-visual alignment with loss â„“câ€‹oâ€‹nsubscriptâ„“ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘›\ell_{con} are both applied.
